pr_title: [RW-4418][risk=low] Add project.rb tool to delete workspaces

timeline.message: fix fetch fc user profile tool
remove dead code and add exception handler

timeline.bodyText: If it's not too tricky, I'd probably return some kind of status for whether the workspace was successfully deleted, wasn't there in the first place, or was otherwise not deletable. Might want to capture this on both our side and the firecloud side.
timeline.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText: my preference is to handle failures through exceptions
replies.author: ericsong

replies.bodyText: But if you're deleting 1000 workspaces and 3 of them fail, an exception at the outer level isn't that helpful. Since we're in an eventually-consistent-ish system, I think you have to consider partial success cases (especially if it's not all in one transaction).
replies.author: jaycarlton

timeline.bodyText: BTW, most of these are coming out soon in favor of the interceptor approach. I'm keeping them in place for a week or so since they're one release ahead and I need to get automation working on the logs-based stuff.
timeline.author: jaycarlton

timeline.bodyText: If you want, you could also inject the auditor into the service and fire from there. This is the only controller that has one I think, and that was due to how it was structured at the time. It's fine here though.
timeline.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText: I left it in the controller because it seemed like that was the level where all of the audit actions were being fired and it made sense to me if the intent is to track user actions
replies.author: ericsong

timeline.bodyText: Was this easier than simply implementing a batch delete API endpoint? I'd rather have swagger boilerplate than have to hack the service injection like this.
timeline.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText: For me, yes. Adding it as an admin endpoint would involve adding a one-off to our API, adding a new authority role, and writing some front end to fire the endpoint. Writing the calls in ruby/node isn't trivial either since we don't have API client packages for either and we'd have to figure out an authentication workflow to fire them.
replies.author: ericsong

replies.bodyText:
I know it feels heavy, but some of these are one-time things that will pay off.
For example, if we don't already have an administrative/devops authority, that's something I'll be wanting. If you want to use Ruby, I've already got a ticket to start generating a client library for that at https://precisionmedicineinitiative.atlassian.net/browse/RW-4499. But really, couldn't you just use curl for this?
The other consideration is that we already have testing patterns for this kind of thing, but with the tools, it's less clear how we make sure they keep working if they're infrequently used.
replies.author: jaycarlton

timeline.bodyText: future: if we determine a useful core of the workspaceService we could break that into its own service and inject the whole thing.
timeline.author: jaycarlton

timeline.bodyText:
This user will actually show up in the audit logs. @calbach and I have been discussing several angles to this problem (i.e. attributing the agent correctly with an anonymous user), and we considered but ultimately shied away from a placeholder user.
How would you feel about providing the username of the devops person running the tool on the command line and looking them up so that we have an actual, helpful user ID & email address in the log?
timeline.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText: I don't think we're logging the delete action ATM.
replies.author: ericsong
